column4: christ Adam_G, did you shut that system down in the middle of an update?
this error first showed up *during* the edgy update
try 'sudo dpkg --configure -a' first, if that's not working though I think you're up the creek without a paddle
thanks, I'll try that, and good to know :D
same thing... oh well... I'm still able to install stuff though, just get a long error message after everything.
if it's any consolation, it looks like only 2 packages are actually failing to configure, the rest are dependencies
I don't suppose they're packages that can easily be removed?
'sudo aptitude clean; sudo aptitude -f install gnome-media-common'
ah, thanks
may/may-not work, but that package is the cause of the trouble
there are some options to force, but they're dangerous (man dpkg for more info on the --force options)
thanks. I've had to force once before... defintely make me nervous. (BTW, same issues with that last command)
from googling error 139 seems to happen when you have corrupted binaries on the system
hmm...
probably a program only those packages are using for configuration, too
so... something tied in with gnome's configuration is corrupted...
I might see if I can get away with taking out as much of gnome as I can...
I'd check your logs to see if it's listed in more detail first
which logs? I don't see anything hopeful in /etc/dpkg or /etc/apt
there's /var/log/dpkg.log
ah, ok :)
I'm gonna get some kip, but to save you the effort I doubt gutting gnome would help
ok. I think I'm going to just let it be as it doesn't interfere with installing anything else
fair enough, good luck with it anyway
